about.formula_en:
The Prognostic Index is calculated based on the following inputs:

Variable

Points

Age at evaluation, years

–

Continuous

Family history of SCD

Hx of sudden cardiac death in ≥1 first degree relatives <40 years of age or SCD in any relative with confirmed HCM at any age

No

0

Yes

1

Maximum wall thickness, mm

Greatest thickness in anterior septum, posterior septum, lateral wall, and posterior wall of the LV, measured at the level of the mitral valve, papillary muscles, and apex, performed with parasternal short-axis plane using 2-D echocardiography at time of evaluation

–

Continuous

Fractional shortening, %

(LV end diastolic dimension – LV end-systolic dimension)/(LV end-diastolic dimension measured by M-Mode or 2-D echocardiography at time of evaluation)

–

Continuous

Left atrial diameter, mm

Determined by M-Mode or 2-D echocardiography in the parasternal long axis place at time of evaluation

–

Continuous

Maximal left ventricular outflow tract gradients, mmHg

Peak outflow tract gradients were determined using the modified Bernoulli equation: Gradient = 4V2, where V is the peak aortic outflow velocity. Determined at rest and with Valsalva provocation using pulsed and continuous wave Doppler from apical 3 and 5-chamber views.

–

Continuous

Non-sustained ventricular tachycardia

≥3 consecutive ventricular beats at a rate of ≥120 bpm and <30 s in duration on Holter monitoring (minimum duration 24 hours) at or prior to evaluation

No

0

Yes

1

Unexplained syncope

Hx of unexplained syncope at or prior to evaluation

No

0

Yes

1

Prognostic Index = 0.15939858*(Maximal wall thickness, mm)  – 0.00294271*(Maximal wall thickness, mm)2 + 0.0259082*(Left atrial diameter, mm) + 0.00446131*(Maximal left ventricular outflow tract gradient, mmHg) + 0.4583082*(Family history of SCD) + 0.82639195*(NSVT) + 0.71650361*(Unexplained syncope) – 0.01799934*(Age at clinical evaluation, years)
about.more_info_en:
The risk of SCD in 5 years for a patient with HCM is calculated by the following:

p̂SCD at 5 years = 1 – 0.998exp(Prognostic Index)

Original/Primary Reference.text: O’Mahony C, Jichi F, Pavlou M, et al. A novel clinical risk prediction model for sudden cardiac death in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (Hcm risk-scd). European Heart Journal. 2014;35(30):2010-2020.

Other References.text: Zeppenfeld K, Tfelt-Hansen J, de Riva M, et al. 2022 ESC Guidelines for the management of patients with ventricular arrhythmias and the prevention of sudden cardiac death. Eur Heart J. 2022;43(40):3997-4126.

Authors/Task Force members, Elliott PM, Anastasakis A, et al. 2014 esc guidelines on diagnosis and management of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: the task force for the diagnosis and management of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy of the european society of cardiology(Esc). Eur Heart J. 2014;35(39):2733-2779.
Monda E, Limongelli G. Integrated sudden cardiac death risk prediction model for patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Circulation. 2023;147(4):281-283.

Validation.text: Vriesendorp PA, Schinkel AFL, Liebregts M, et al. Validation of the 2014 European Society of Cardiology guidelines risk prediction model for the primary prevention of sudden cardiac death in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Circ Arrhythm Electrophysiol. 2015;8(4):829-835.

O’Mahony C, Jichi F, Ommen SR, et al. International external validation study of the 2014 european society of cardiology guidelines on sudden cardiac death prevention in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy(Evidence-hcm). Circulation. 2018;137(10):1015-1023.

how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• Should not be used in pediatric patients (those younger than 16 years of age).
  • Should not be used in elite/competitive athletes.
  • Should not be used in patients who have metabolic diseases or syndromes that are associated with a diagnosis of HCM.

next_steps.advice_en: Do you use HCM Risk-SCD and want to contribute your expertise? Join our contributor team!

input_schema.name: scd
input_schema.tips_en: Hx of sudden cardiac death in >1 first degree relatives <40 years of age or SCD in any relative with confirmed <abbr title="Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy">HCM</abbr> at any age

input_schema.name: max_wall
input_schema.tips_en: Greatest thickness in anterior septum, posterior septum, lateral wall, and posterior wall of the LV, measured at the level of the mitral valve, papillary muscles, and apex

input_schema.name: frac_short
input_schema.tips_en: (LV end diastolic dimension – LV end-systolic dimension)/(LV end-diastolic dimension measured by M-Mode or 2-D echocardiography at time of evaluation)

input_schema.name: lad
input_schema.tips_en: Determined by M-Mode or 2-D echocardiography in the parasternal long axis place at time of evaluation

input_schema.label_en: Maximal left ventricular outflow tract gradients, mmHg
input_schema.name: lv_outflow
input_schema.tips_en: Determined at rest and with Valsalva provocation using pulsed and continuous wave Doppler from apical 3 and 5-chamber views

input_schema.name: nsvt
input_schema.tips_en: ≥3 consecutive ventricular beats at a rate of ≥120 bpm and <30 s in duration on Holter monitoring (minimum duration 24 hours) at or prior to evaluation

input_schema.name: syncope
input_schema.tips_en: Hx of unexplained syncope at or prior to evaluation

calc.instructions_en: This tool estimates the 5-year risk of sudden cardiac death in patients ≥16 years of age after their initial evaluation.
calc.medium_description_en: Estimates risk of sudden cardiac death in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

seo.keywords_en: HCM Risk-SCD, HCM, SCD, sudden, sudden cardiac death, sudden cardiac, cardiac death, cardiomyopathy, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, hcm risk, hcm risk scd, scd risk, hcm scd, scd hcm
seo.meta_description_en: HCM Risk-SCD estimates risk of sudden cardiac death in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

creators.about_en: Constantinos O’Mahony, MD, is an honorary associate professor at the Institute of Cardiovascular Science at University College London and a consultant cardiologist at St. Bartholomew’s Hospital and Whipps Cross Hospital. He is a member of various cardiology societies, such as the British Cardiovascular Intervention Society and European Society of Cardiology. Dr. O’Mahony’s primary research is focused on clinical outcomes in cardiomyopathies and novel treatments.
creators.name: Dr. Constantinos O’Mahony

cme_faq.answer: MDCalc’s Continuing Medical Education (CME) service allows users to easily earn AMA PRA Category 1 CreditsTM through regular use of MDCalc. Simply put, on top of getting the best medical calculators in the world, your usage will help you achieve your annual CME requirements, including specialty CME, without any extra effort.
cme_faq.question: What is MDCalc CME?

cme_faq.answer: Yes, in support of improving patient care, this activity has been planned and implemented by the Postgraduate Institute for Medicine and MDCalc Ltd. Inc. Postgraduate Institute for Medicine is jointly accredited by the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education (ACCME), the Accreditation Council for Pharmacy Education (ACPE), and the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC), to provide continuing education for the healthcare team.
cme_faq.question: Is MDCalc CME accredited?

cme_faq.answer: Only United States attending physicians, nurse practitioners, nurses, and physician assistants are eligible for our CME service.
cme_faq.question: Who can enroll and how?

cme_faq.answer: We have over 275 CME-eligible calculators across various specialties. You can read the clinical content supporting any CME calculators to start earning. Once you have viewed all the supporting content for a calculator, you will have officially earned the credit amount (0.5 credits) and will be able to redeem a certificate. For now, only calc content in CME-eligible calcs is eligible for CME credits, however, we’ll be expanding our CME service to include more of our content in the future.
cme_faq.question: What activities can I do to earn CME credits?

cme_faq.answer: Simply use our search bar or visit our homepage to easily find CME-eligible calcs. You must be enrolled in our CME service to see which calcs are CME-eligible.
cme_faq.question: Where can I find calcs with which I can earn credits?

cme_faq.answer: Once you’ve enrolled in our CME service, you will have a personal CME Dashboard where you can view all of your earned credits. You can navigate to the dashboard by clicking the CME button in the header at the top of any page.
cme_faq.question: Where can I see which credits I’ve earned?

cme_faq.answer: Go to your CME Dashboard and select the credits you’d like to redeem, fill out a few dropdown answers about how you used the calc, and then proceed to checkout.
cme_faq.question: How do I redeem CME credits?

cme_faq.answer: No. Earning credits as you use calcs is free, but either you (or your employer) will need to purchase an annual subscription to redeem your CME certificates.
cme_faq.question: Are CME credits free?

cme_faq.answer: Just like with earned credits, you can view your CME certificates on your CME Dashboard in the “CME Certificates” tab. Certificates include a list of all of the calcs for which CME was earned along with a tally of the specialty CME.
cme_faq.question: Where can I see my CME certificates?

cme_faq.answer: One year from the date of purchase.
cme_faq.question: How long do credits in an annual subscription last?

cme_faq.answer: General; Addiction and Controlled Substances; Cardiac Care; Domestic and Intimate Partner Violence; Geriatrics; HIV and Infectious Disease; Hospice, End-of-Life, Terminal Illness, and Palliative Care; Mental and Behavioral Health; Pain Management; Pediatrics; Stroke; and Trauma.
cme_faq.question: What specialty CME credits are included in the plan?

cme_faq.answer:
Your gift card will be sent via email within 1-2 business days of making your purchase. You will be able to select from the following options - Visa, Amazon.com, Apple. Be sure to claim your gift card offer within 90 days of receiving the email.

Your CME purchase may have implications for tax reporting purposes. The cost of your CME product may or may not be tax-deductible when used for professional purposes. Any reimbursed amount for incentives must be declared as personal income for tax purposes. Please consult your tax advisor. MDCalc does not provide tax advice.
cme_faq.question: I ordered a CME package with a gift card. How does it work?

cme_faq.answer: Per the new guidelines from ACCME, the receipt will separate the cost you paid into the cost of the gift card and the cost of the CME learning activity.
cme_faq.question: What will show on my receipt for CME when it includes a gift card?

cme_faq.answer: You can get a refund (minus any promotional gift amount) within 30-days if the ease of earning and redeeming does not meet your expectations and if you have redeemed no more than 4 credits. Please email team@mdcalc.com to request a refund.
cme_faq.question: How do I get a refund if I'm not satisfied?

cme_faq.answer: You can upgrade your subscription throughout your billing cycle and pay the difference for a higher plan. You may request to downgrade your plan to a lower level to coincide with your next renewal. Please email team@mdcalc.com to request changes.
cme_faq.question: How do I later upgrade to a different plan if I need more credits?

cme_faq.answer: Gift card plans are available for 1 year and do not auto-renew. Standard, non gift-card subscriptions are auto-renewed annually. You can disable the automatic renewal of your subscription at any time by emailing team@mdcalc.com.
cme_faq.question: Do CME plans auto-renew?

cme_faq.answer: If you’re part of a team or practice that wants to sign up five or more physicians, please email us at team@mdcalc.com for more information.
cme_faq.question: How do I get information on a discounted bulk subscription program for my institution, team, or practice?

cme_faq.answer: On July 28, 2022, ACCME updated the guidelines regarding the use of high-value incentives. These guidelines allow for the use of gift card rewards in a regulated manner. Visit the ACCME website to read their guidelines.
cme_faq.question: Did the ACCME decide to regulate gift cards?
